statement.tex: %text Find the area of the circle $4x^2+4y^2=9$ which is interior to the parabola $x^2=4y$. %
\\ %text What is the \underline\text{radius} of the given circle? %
\\ %text Which of the figures below correctly identifies the required area? %
\\ \textbf{Points of intersection}\\ %text What are the coordinates of points $A$ and $B$ where the two curves intersect? %
\\ %text What will be the expression for the required area (as shown in the last step)? %

\\ %text Given that, \[ R = \underbrace{2\int_0^\sqrt{2}\sqrt{\frac{9}{4}-x^2}\cdot dx}_P - \underbrace{2\int_0^\sqrt{2}\frac{x^2}{4}\cdot dx}_Q\] are the following \underline\text{values of $P,Q$ and $R$} correct? %

reason.tex:
%text In the figures, \underline\text{point p} is inside the parabola and \underline\text{point q} is outside.
Hence, the bit of the circle that is \underline\text{inside} the parabola is as shown in the correct option. %

%text The two curves will intersect when % \begin{align} x^2 = \underbrace{\frac{9}{4}-y^2}_{\text{circle}} &= \underbrace{4y}_{\text{parabola}} \\ \implies 4y^2 + 16y - 9 &= 0 \\ \text{or }(2y+9)\cdot (2y-1) &= 0\implies y=-\frac{9}{2},\frac{1}{2} \end{align} %text
But we can see \underline\text{from the figure} that for both $A$ and $B, \underline{y\gt 0}$. Therefore, $y=\frac{1}{2}$. % \begin{align} \text{Hence, }x^2 &= 4y = 4\cdot\frac{1}{2} = 2 \\ \implies x &= \pm\sqrt{2} \\ \implies A &=\left(-\sqrt{2},\frac{1}{2} \right) \text{ and }B = \left( \sqrt{2},\frac{1}{2}\right) \end{align}

\begin{align} R &= \underbrace{2\int_0^\sqrt{2}\sqrt{\frac{9}{4}-x^2}\cdot dx}_P - \underbrace{2\int_0^\sqrt{2}\frac{x^2}{4}\cdot dx}_Q\\ P &= 2\int_0^\sqrt{2}\underbrace{\sqrt{\left(\frac{3}{2}\right)^2-x^2}}_{a=\frac{3}{2}}\cdot dx \\ &= 2\cdot\left[ \frac{a^2}{2}\sin^{-1}\frac{x}{a}+ \frac{x}{2}\sqrt{a^2-x^2}\right]_0^\sqrt{2} \\ &= 2\cdot\left[ \left(\frac{\frac{9}{4}}{2}\sin^{-1}\frac{\sqrt{2}}{\frac{3}{2}}+ \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\sqrt{\frac{9}{4}-2}\right)- 0\right] \\ &= \frac{9}{4}\sin^{-1}\frac{2\sqrt{2}}{3} + \sqrt{2}\frac{1}{2} \\ &= \frac{9}{4}\sin^{-1}\frac{2\sqrt{2}}{3} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\ Q &= 2\int_0^\sqrt{2}\frac{x^2}{4}\cdot dx = \left[ \frac{x^3}{6}\right]_0^\sqrt{2} = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{3} \\ \therefore R &= \frac{9}{4}\sin^{-1}\frac{2\sqrt{2}}{3} + \underbrace{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}- \frac{\sqrt{2}}{3}}_{\text{Simplify}} \\ &= \frac{9}{4}\sin^{-1}\frac{2\sqrt{2}}{3} + \frac{1}{3\sqrt{2}} \end{align}
